posts.name: Drake Christianson
posts.cooked: How would I go about running a command when an xbox trigger is pressed? They are read as axes, not buttons, but I would like to run the motor at a set speed when the trigger is beyond a certain point.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Google “wpilib TriggerButton” and you’ll find MANY options

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Feel free and use our implementation if you’d like.

Go to github and search, there are likely similar but better options than ours.

To answer your more fundamental question of how do I turn an analog axis into a digital button:

You need to understand the underlying WPILib functions that provide buttons, and extend that understanding to the actual trigger you’re trying to implement.  The idea here in our implementation is something along the lines of: Treat the axis as digital, either on or off. The default condition of ‘on’ is when the analog axis reads a certain threshold.

posts.name: Drake Christianson
posts.cooked: I tried using ‘’‘Trigger intakeTrigger = new Trigger(() → xbox.getRawAxis(2) > 0.65);’’’ to create a trigger and ‘’‘intakeTrigger.whenActive(new runIntake(m_intakeSubsystem));’’’ to run the command, but it is not outputting a signal to drive the motor. Am I missing something with this?

posts.name: Drake Christianson
posts.cooked: Also it works fine with a regular button, just not the axis input.

posts.name: Drake Christianson
NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked: Did you instantiate xlt before calling whileHeld() ?  The stacktrace suggests you didn’t.

posts.name: Drake Christianson
posts.cooked: This fixed it, thank you so much!

posts.name: CJ Hill
posts.cooked:
In case anyone from the robotpy (Python) user community lands here, we had a real headscratcher going to the commands2 AxisButton.  Seems like get() was no longer called in v2, and the isPressed had to be set in the Button’s init() - at least, it didn’t work when we tried to redefine isPressed() the same way we did get() in the old version.

Working commands1 version:

from wpilib.command import Button from wpilib import Joystick

class AxisButton(Button):

Working commands2 version:

from commands2.button import Button from wpilib import XboxController

class AxisButton(Button):

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
